text: On tap at Elysian Fields. Pours a hazy copper with medium frothy off white head. The aroma is grass and earthy malt. Medium body, nice hop bite, earth, bitter finish, good.
On tap at the brewery. Cloudy golden pour with a white head. Bitter and kind of hoppy for an ESB, some biscuit notes and fruit, tropical and citrus zest. Not bad.

Rating #1972 2015.09.26 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 3, Beer 73 Draught at Taphouse Grill. Pours a deep golden colour with a foamy white head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma is toffee, honey, toasted barley. Hop presence is significant, giving the bitter character of grassy, earthiness with a hint of toffee honey sweetness. Well balanced, medium bodied ale that is easy to drink.
Pours a nice hazy golden orange color. Aromas of nice citrus/grapefruit hops. Flavor starts malty and the hops kick in, nice crisp bitter finish.

On June 25, 2015. At Elysian Capitol Hill in Seattle, Washington.Clear copper to amber color, yellow head with lacing. Hoppy, fruity taste. Light pith aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Malty scent.

4 oz pour from tap into a cylindrical tasting glass at the brewery in Seattle. Deep orange, mostly clear, big fluffy white head. Full body (especially for the abv) and creamy. Fairly crisp. Nose is malty and not too much else. Taste is a pretty straight forward ESB. A few layers of maltiness with an herby, hoppy finish.

Aroma: light grain, cereals. Appearance: hazy brown, medium, creamy, beige head. Taste: medium bitter. Palate: flowers, light sweet malts coming up again, medium body. Overall: OK ESB, but nothing to write home about. Pint at Big Brew, Morristown.

"a smooth creamy representation of the style, but its a little unassuming compared to many of their other beers. well balnced, light and refreshing...nothing more or less. had again, and i appreciate how it stands up, at least a little, to elysians bigger brews."
This beer has some nice flavor, typical of the style, which is surprising for a ESB from Washington.
Out of the many from Elysian Ive sampled, this isnt my fav. Flavorful and true to style enough, but I never order it.

On tap @ Elysian Capitol Hill. Cloudy orange pour with white foam. Smells like popcorn. Really toasty, too. Some grass, pine, and herbal hops. Somewhat fruity and earthy. Flavor is bland and grainy. Lots of toasted grains and popcorn. Bitter herbs and grass. Some apple esters and dry straw.
On tap at Elysian Fields. Pours a copper color with white head. Caramel, earthy, noble hop flavors. Pretty nice esb.

On tap @ the brewery during 7/5/2014 Seattle beer tour. Pours a burnt orange appearance with a cream colored head. Earthy, caramel malty nose with a hint of citrus. Nice mouth feel. Medium body. Fairly sweet flavor. Caramel and oranges. Fine.

On tap @ McGivneys.
This was poured into a pint glass.
The appearance was a nice looking hazy orange to brown color with a good bar pour that didnt yield any head, however, there was a decent amount of light clingy lacing sliding into the body.
The aroma smelled like any other typical ESB (British malt-like but not soapy).
The taste was malty with a little bit of light apples here and there. There was a nice light malty aftertaste that ended up leading towards a malty dry like finish.
On the palate, it sat about a light to medium and showed a decent sessionable quality running over my mouth and tongue.
Overall, I say this was a pretty good ESB well worthy of having again.

Solid ruby or brown with a bit of offwhite head. Little to no scent, citrus hops, some graininess and iron. Very thin mouthfeel. Taste is malty, astringent, some carmel and floral hops. Somewhat hoppy ESB. Decent.

Bottled: unk
Pours a nice amber ale with some surface foam and a spotty lace. Smells of amber malts, some metal, some herbal hops, some hints of herbs. Really, overall nose is inoffensive and approachable with a hint of sweetness - as I believe an ESB should be, fine work Dick. Flavor hits with well steeped black tea, some sweet and English malts and a bit of herbal hops sans bitterness. Nice ESB flavor. Medium bodied with reserved carb and a semi wet finish. Nice beer. ESBs are one to feel good drinking and drinking and drinking...This has that. Unobtrusive and approachable - not the most unique, but thats what makes it good!

Serving type: bottle

05-07-2012

Cloudy copper. Sips citrus and silky smooth with bitter hop middle and finish. More bitter than with very slight malt character. Of course this is Washington so an esp would be overly bitter compared to European version. Overall I like though.

Pours mahogany finger off white head.

Smell clean caramel and slight toffee, grassy hops.

Taste slight red fruit. Caramel and earthy grassy hops.

Clean and easy drinking.

Really good esb

Draft at Pour House, pours hazy copper with light head and not much lacing. Aroma of almonds, chocolate, hazelnut, milk, malt, and other nutty tones. Taste is milk chocolate, rye, creamy malt, and bitter grain. Good bit of columbus coming through as well. Light to medium body. Nice ESB.
Draft at the source. Clear golden color, medium white head. Aroma of grapefruit and pineapple. Taste is crisp bitter fruit.

Tap. Poured clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate complex hop and earthy malt aroma. Medium body with a smoot texture and soft carbonation. Medium toasted bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.
Poured from tap at the Elysian brewery in Capitol Hill/Seattle. Amber orange with foamy head. Definatly bitter. Smooth though. butterscotch and malty. Good for the style.

Tap at Elysian on E Pike, Seattle, 27/05/13.
Lightly hazed golden amber with a good sized off white head that retains well.
Nose is hops, grapefruit, bitter orange, caramel malt.
Taste comprises orange pith, light grapefruit notes, grass, hop bitterness.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, light hop bitterness in the finish.
This is a tasty drop but way too hoppy to be considered an ESB ! 
Dear brewer ... come to England and try some ESBs - not knocking your beer I enjoyed it but not what it says on the tin my old bean !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Toffee biscuit marmelade and vegetal notes on nose.  Nice orange amber pour decent head good lace. Flavors of toffee marmelade and vegetal hops. Moderate hop bitterness easy drinkability somewhat unremarkable.
On tap at Elysian Brewhouse, Seattle. Unfortunatelly bad Bitter, one is enough for ever...
Hearty citrus aroma, especially. grapefruit. Flavor is more of the same, complimented by doughy malt. Amber-red hue, not too heady on tap. More American pale than English ESB.
On tap at St Augustines. Pours a clear dark amber with little head. Floral and citrus hop aroma. Flavor of malts and light citrus with moderate bitter finish. Nothing special.

650ml bomber pours a slightly hazy orangey amber color with a finger and a half of white head that leaves some thin spotty lacing behind.  Aroma is caramel with some citrus and grass.  Taste is a caramel malty sweetness with the citrus and grass hop bitterness.  Very well balanced brew that is medium bodied with some nice carbonation providing great sensations on the palate.  This is one of the better ESBs I have tried to date and highly recommended.

I enjoy a good ESB and this might have been the best Ive had. Having from a hand pump at the brewery didnt hurt either. Pours a cloudy amber with a red tint. The aroma is all malt with some bread, yeast, caramel. The flavor has that and is balanced perfectly with the hops. Excellent.
Deep red character and good hoppy body accentuate this unique ESB. Head is non-present, with a nice gentle, but satisfying finish.

Copper amber with an off-white head. Aroma is slightly sweet malts, herbal, light citrus hops, and some bread. Medium body. Flavor is nice sweet malts, dough, a bit of zesty citrus hops. Light but sharp bitter bite on the back end. Highly enjoyable.
22 oz Bottle.  Pours a hazy gold amber with light off-white head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malts.  Flavor is smooth and mostly malty, with a slight bitterness in the finish.  Pretty good.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2011 Pint from cask at The Met in NW. Color is a medium to darker amber; quite cloudy. Aroma and taste are very hoppy indeed. A bit too much so for my taste, but a great example of its type.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2011 On tap @ Valhalla w Brandon and Erica. Nice dark red pour with medium white head. Aroma is burnt/toasted malt and a bit of caramel. Palate is mostly hop bitterness and a little sweetness. This is a rich, bitter beer with a medium-heavy mouthfeel. Not bad.
Really not my thing. Bitter metallic finish ruined it for me; the hops seemed very recognizable (spot the Cascades!) and it made for an undistinctive beer with negatives. (on tap at brewpub)

Pint at Elysian fields location..good aroma, bitter. Nutty caramel, citric  bite. Brownish orange color, ok head, good lace. Bitter flavor.medium body, thick creamy mouthfeel. Dry finish. Pretty darn good. Nice bite in flavor. Aroma opened up nicely as warmed.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
Thanks to 5000 for sending me this bottle. 

The beer pours a hazy orange-amber color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the papaya with some biscuit malt and grassy hops mixed in. The flavor is full of hop flavor. I get a lot of juicy orange notes, but the bitterness from the hops is negated by the biscuit and toffee malt. Overall, the bitterness is pretty low. There is also a little bit of grass from the hops. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very well balanced ESB. Very nice.

Bomber Bottle, 

this beer had a hazy dark red pour with various dark red hues and brown colors at the sides of the glass, the pour made a one finger head of off-white & light tan colored head that receded to a partial cover and small ring, this ale was too dark to see through but I could see bubbles at the sides of the glass, there were spots and fingers of lacing on the sides of the glass, I found a thin layer of dark sediment on the bottom of the bottle, 

this ale had nice aromas of caramel, chocolate, toasted malt, faint earthy hops in the background with brown sugar sweetness, there was faint fruit in the background (the caramel and chocolate were up front in this drink), 

the flavors were malty with toasted malt, chocolate and caramel, there was some hop bitterness to give balance, 

the mouth feel was a little less than medium and gave some creaminess on the palate, 

this was a nice drink, I enjoyed the aroma and flavor of this drink with the balance of malt and hops, I wish this beer was available in Michigan.

Draught at the Alibi Room, VancouverHazy copper color; creamy head. The aroma has some caramel and its a bit nutty and dusty. Quite good caramel flavor, nutty, with moderate residual sweetness, and good bitterness level; the hop is quite resiny, but not much fruity.Good.

Dark amber color, small steady off-white head, lace. Nutty, woody, a bit hoppy nose. Medium-bodied. Woody, citrusy hoppyness. Some nuttyness, but a bit too hoppy and too little caramel for ESB. Ok APA :)

Sampled from a 22oz brown bottle this beer poured a hazy caramel-brown color with a large fluffy orange-cream head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was tart apple, pear and almost cinnamon. The flavor was tart and tangy apple, pear, nut, nutmeg and caramel. Medium length tangy finish. Medium body. Decent.

Draught @ The Alibi Room, Vancouver, BC

Pours copper/amber with a foamy head. Aroma has notes of hops and grass. Taste is quite bitter with slight notes of pine and hops. Smooth finish, great ESB.

Aroma is earthy, amber-ish malts; also a pale-chlorine quality. Dusty brown sugar.

The appearance is cloudy copper orange. Not much carbonation but a big head. Specks of lace. Slushy head remains.

The flavor is sugary English-style bitter flavors. Sweet, nutty, malty. Hops are a flowery, herbal accent. Much more rounded off than the prickly aroma. 

The palate is fizzy anf fuzzy. Leaves a dry, dusty finish. A very nutty, English ESB; sugary but not saccharine. Dry and very British, and quite drinkable.

Bomber. Light amber and copper colored in appearance with a good inch of dense off-white head. Mostly caramel and bready malt notes in the aroma with a little bit of earthy hops. The taste is primarily a blend of caramel malt, toffee, biscuits and citrusy (orange, grapefruit) hops. The body is smooth and creamy with medium carbonation and finishes dry with some hops bitterness. Overall, a tasty brew that starts strong on the malt but finishes with a shot of hops flavors.

Nice coppery pour with a grass and prange peel aroma. A mild grapefruit taste with a dry hoppy finish.

Pretty damn good for the style.

Such a tasty brew!  22oz bomber purchased from Brewforia.com.  Aroma brings a nice balance of nutty malts, sweet caramel, and a twist of piney hops.  Flavor goes through a steady progression with caramel dominating the front, with earthy malts and piney hops fighting each other for balance through the middle, finishing with dry, bitter piney hops.  Generally creamy mouthfeel, no over-the-top flavors blasting your palate away, just a powerful ESB with great depth of flavor, aroma, and balance.

Location: Sampled at the NY Brewfest on Governors Island, 6/19/10


Aroma: Hoppy notes on the nose, pine, some wood, and a bit of caramel

Appearance: This is a caramel colored beer with a beige head

Flavor: It has a balanced flavor, medium sweet, medium bitter

Palate: The body is medium with a soft mouthfeel and a dry finish

Overall Impression: 
Overall, I thought this was a pretty good beer.  It is a nice example of an American style ESB.  Id drink this one again.

1 oz Sample at the GABF in Denver.  Fantasic copper rust color in the sample cup.  Lively citrus hop aromas and flavors balanced with carmal malts and spice.  Medium carbonation and long lasing end bitterness.
22 oz bomber. Looks like a beer should. Cloudy amber color and a thin off-white head that laces the glass. Taste is malty and bitter with a dry finish. Good ESB for sure!

On tap at Taphouse Grill, Seattle.  Pours a clear copper color with thin white head with decent retention and lacing.  Aroma of sweet caramel and a hint of grassy hops.  Flavor starts with lots of caramel sweetness up front, but gives way to some nice citrusy and peppery hop bitterness.  Medium mouthfeel and pleasantly dry finish.  Very nice beer.

22 oz. bottle, pours caramel orange with almost no head. Aroma of caramel malts and hops - nice balance. Flavour follows pretty similarly, with caramel malts and toffee on the palate, and a hoppy finish. Very well brewed.
West USA trip 2010. On tap at the brewpub. The aroma has some malts and flowers. Clear, amber coloured brew with a thin, white head. The taste has some pine hops, bitterness and maltiness.

Pours dark ruby amber, thin beige head leaves a ring. Aroma of caramel, toffee, mild citrus. Taste is maltier than expected, very little hop up front but the finish has some resin and burnt malt. Great balance overall, medium body, soft carbonation. Good price.
Tap at Maggios. Pours a rich copper with sticky thin head. Malt is up front and significant. Hops are more subdued to me. Tasty and easily sessionable.

On  tap at the brewpub in Seattle on Pike. Pours a copper hue with a medium white head. The aroma is lots of metallic hops. The flavor is a very nice hoppy ESB; rich caramel, sweet citrus hops, loads of malt background. Nice.

(Old BA rate - bottle)
Thin white head, with a deep copper-brown color. Wonderful malty, prune-like aromas (not too overpowering though)Balanced flavors throughout, biscuits, dry hop bitterness toward the end. Great malt back. Thinnish MF, with tight bubbly carbonation. Huge on the drinkability front. Great balance of all elements of the brew, and the dry finish is really appetizing. I could have easily quaffed this brew all evening.  Not too heavy-handed on the hops.

Pours opaque and copper colored with an off-white head. Piney, floral hops predominate with hints of citrus fruits and caramel malt. Bitterness is upfront with a calming malty backbone, hopiness recurring in the finished. Palate is medium and resinous. A very good ESB that I would like to pair with a sweet and spicy meal.
Some times I am a man of few words. This beer was good.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2010 The Wise ESB

1999 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Hazy rich copper golden color.  Light sediment adds to rich lacy head.  Malty hoppy light floral front.  Smooth rich ESB doughy sweet caramel biscuit body.  Floral hops flash in smooth spicy finish.  Sampled 12/25/1999.

2000 22 oz. Bottle.  6.00% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Clear rich copper bronze color.  Smooth floral toasted hop front.  Crisp ESB toasted fruit malt body with a touch of doughiness.  Mild light hop finish.  Very clean smooth mild ESB flavor.  Sampled 12/14/2000.

2004-B 22 oz. Bottle Extra Special Bitter--Athena Goddess of Wisdom Graphic.  5.90% ABV--45 IBUs.?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Mild lacy head.  Clear rich deep amber color.  Mild toasted malty earty floral hop front.  Crisp creamy malty sweet earthy toasted caramel body.  Clean dry crusty hop spice mild citrus end.  Classic!  Sampled 12/9/2004.

2004 Great American Beer Festival Gold Medal Winner Sticker 22 oz. Bottle.  6.13% ABV--45 IBUs.?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Rich lacy head.  Clear garnet amber red color  .Malty mild hop toasted malty front.  Sweet smooth creamy toasted doughy caramel mild earthy fruit body.  Rich clean earthy bitter creamy hop end.  Tasty.  Sampled 8/15/2004.

2008 ELYSIAN 22 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV--39 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Rich dense lacy head.  Cold hazed rich bright copper red amber color.  Mild toasted malty mild hop front.  Light sediment.  Creamy mild earthy rich malty mild toasted caramel toffee mild sweet fruit hint smooth body.  Cloying malt smooth balanced mild hop spice end.  Sampled 7/2/2008.  4 @ $3.33 Each.

Elysian Brewing Company, Inc.--ELYSIAN The Wise ESB--2010 22 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  39 IBUs.  (3.5 / 5.0)  Thin mild lace off white head.  Slightly hazy bright rich dark amber ruby color.  Lightly toasted mild hop front.  Crisp light toasted caramel biscuit earthy hint medium ESB body.  Dry mildly bitter light hop spice end.  Smooth refreshing but dead taste buds bland.  Sampled 8/27/2010.  2 @ $3.99.

Bomber.  Pours a slightly hazy, deep, dark red-amber color.  A tall, frothy head of beige tinted foam is well retained, slowly fading to a thick, pronounced edge of bubbles.  Sticky, cobweb-like sheeting coats the glass very well.  The nose is very well balanced, showing softly sweet, creamy biscuit and toast malt in the forefront, with a substantive, grassy hop bitterness as the counterpoint.  Flavors are equally smooth, transitioning effortlessly between the toasty-sweet biscuit, with its soft, lactic creaminess, to a lightly bitter, peppery floral and grassy finish.  Simple, yet effective.  Likewise, the palate is easy going, but substantive, with a medium-weight body and a creamy, almost whipped consistency.  Fine brew.  Sessionable.

Bomber from Perrys Liquors. Nose of grassy, flowery hops and some light caramel and fruity notes. Lightly hazy reddish copper with a small beige head. Flavor is lightly bitter over a caramel malt background.

(bottle - 22 oz) Copper pour with a thin layer of white foam and very subdued carbonation. Mild malty aroma with some hints of caramel and a definite hop presence at the end. Flavor is nice and malty at the beginning but quickly fades to a bitter and peppery hop middle. You can definitely taste the Chinook as it nears the finish and dries out, leaving a pleasantly bitter finish on the tongue.

Bottle. Hazy orange amber with a thick beige head.  Nutty toffee and floral resinous hop aromas vie for attention. Toffee and nutty malt flavours with delicious floral fruity hops (orange blossom, tangerine) and a big resinous bitter finish.  Delicious!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle 650ml.Clear medium orange amber color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, pine, orange. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090813]
pours a deep red with nice white head. decent aroma for an esb and a nice hop presence. malty bit not sweet a nice finish.

Bottle. 22 oz. Pours slightly cloudy amber with a fresh, floral, tan head. Aroma of hops, vanilla, caramel, lavender, barley, and sweet malts. Medium bodied with a smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Modest warming in the finish, which is slow burning and nice. Great bitter. Tastes more like a moderate IPA.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2009 On-tap @ Tangletown, E-Fields, and Serious Pie.  Great british malt backbone, complex profile with toffee sweetness and a light hop aroma.  Very quaffable and a "wise" choice so to speak.  No flaws and incredibly consistent from tap to bottle, pairs well with a lot of different meals.

22oz from ditmeir - thanks, Eric! Nice hazy amber pour with a moderate head that reduces quickly. Sweet floral hops in the aroma along with some fragrant toffee notes, very inviting and balanced. The mouthfeel is nice and full, and the candied flavors mingle very nicely with the flavorful style, and it tapers off with a pleasantly dry finish. Really fine example of the style to me.

On tap at the Elysian Fields pub. Colour... amber-orange, no head. Nose... nice balance between malt and hops. Palate... fairly one dimensional (like most ESBs). Light malt, faint hops on the finish.
Pours an orange amber, leaving oodles of white lace.  Aromas of biscuit, nuttiness, some peppery earthy hops.  Tastes of piney bitterness, with a slight nutty caramel lingering.  Enjoyed.

On tap at Stanton Public, NY. Light clear copper color, off wite thick foamy head. Aroma of toasty grassy caramel malt, light floral hop. Flavor is mildly bitter floral hop, a little earthy, but much less malt in flavor. Hop aftertaste.
Pours a hazy copper color with a tan head.  Aroma is slightly musty, caramel, toast, and some earthy hops. Flavor is caramel, toast, and some earthy citrus.
Bottle 65 cl. Clear amber golden with a small off-white head. Aroma of nuts and aroma hops. Medium body, sweet caramel and spicy aroma hops. Finishes dry. 130809
Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of sweet malt, caramel, and alcohol. The flavor is sweet and mainly malty, leading to a bitter finish.
Bottle from Bottle Barn.  Nice copper brown with a fizzy off white head.  Brassy earthy hops aroma and a deep grassy taste with a crisp clean finish.  Very drinkable.

Pours a clear amber with a good off-white head. The aroma is of some sweet malt, caramel, and fruity hops. The taste is clean. Lots of bitterness up front, but balanced with a good amount of malt. This has pleanty of piney, fruity, caramel, and bready notes. This is a good medium-full body beer with a crisp bitter finish. This is well balanced and a very nice drinker. Well done Elysian.

Bottle at Papsø.
Cloudy orange coloured with a small off white ehad.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, hops and grass.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, hops and grape fruits with notes of grass.
Dry hoppy finish.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2012 22 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy dark orange with a fully gone head. Aroma is hoppy, light pinewood, grassy and vague citrusy. Citrusy and wooden hops flavoured, light liqourice and roasted caramelish malt flavoured base. Bitter and fruity finish.7-3-7-7=14

From tap at the Pike brewpub. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is toasted malty and crisp hopppy. Bitter, crisp hoppy and smooth to lingering fruity hops into the finish.7-3-7-7=14
Clear amber with a off white head. Sweet aroma with hops, pine and caramel notes. Flavour was quite hoppy with pine, lemons and a bitter finish.
Draft @ RnH.  Weak looking pour, clear amber.  Nose is of fresh cut wood, hop Taste is dry hop,  nut, toasty. Bright on the palate.

RBSG09 on tap at the Rogue Publick House in SF. Pours golden amber with a thin off-white head. Floral apple juice aroma and some earthiness and bread. Flavor is lightly doughy with floral hops, apples, light grapefruit. Too sweet, needs more earthy hops. Pretty drinkable. Dry on the palate.

This is a reddish-brown beer with no head at all. Wait... no, I think I see a head... yes, theres a thin layer of something white on top. That must be the head. Ill have to look at it under a microscope to be sure. Aroma is malty with some sour hop smell. If I were in a generous mood, I would say that it has a hint of lemon. Flavor is about the same, malt, hops, some pine. Rather bitter when it hits the back of the tongue. Very drinkable, but there is nothing extra special about it.

Cask at Elysians SBW Firkin-Firkin throwdown (vs. Marin ESB).  Pours cloudy orange amber with a nice off-white head.  Funky citrus/pine and oatmeal in the aroma and taste.  Not really what I was expecting from an ESB, but neither was the Marin, and this one was slightly better.

On tap at Toronado in San Francisco. Pours a clear, darker copper body with a finger-width, off-white head that dissipates into a moderate lacing. Aroma is heavy and sweet caramels with a light toasted toffee. A moderate pine and light fruits go well with the big, sweet malts. Flavor is similar and well balanced. Lots of full caramels and just a touch of toasted toffees. Dry and malty in the finish with lots of moderate pine bitterness. Overall, a solid ESB with a nice balance and bigger body. Lots of caramels and lots of hops. Good one.
On tap at Toronado. This dark amber ale poured with a modest beige head and a caramel aroma. There is a sweet malt flavor with plenty of hop bitterness.
Draft.  Coper penny in color, pure white head.  Sweet and citrusy aroma, flavor is citrusy hops, sweet sugary malts, metallic note to the finish.

Bomber from the rip and run.  A clear amber with steady carbonation yeilding a decent regenerative head. Alternating wash of hops then malt.  Some overripe fruit covered in caramel tones distract me from the initial refreshing mouthfeel.  Finish is a bit muddled from this and slightly hoppy.

Deep amber coloured body with a very thin off-white head. Aroma of malt and nuts. Medium-bodied; Clean nutty flavours in the taste override all the hops. Aftertaste shows more clean nutty flavours on the palate with strong alcohol and a light english hop taste. Overall, decent, but the amnesia bitter is better. I sampled this as my final beer in Portland, Oregon on 09-September-2006.

Bottle from Bottle Trek via an internet order. Poured a clear bronze color with the smell of carmel coming from my glass. Wonderful balance of hops and malts which my this style on of the most drinkable for me. This beer was excellent!!

Bottle sampled at SF International Beer Fest.  Copper color with an nice off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malt and citrusy hops.  Flavor is more of the same, northwest-style C-hops stand out, which I think work really well in this style.  Medium body.

$3.49 @ Bottle Barn--I think this is my first Elysian beer.  22oz, no date.  Clear copper orange with a two-finger light yellowish white head, good retention.  Some caramel malts are dominant with just a touch of toasted malts.  I can only pick up on a little generic citrus hops (Cascade, I think).  Flavor is much the same with lots of caramel and a little toasted malts, but seemed a little bland.  Not much hop presence, though bitterness was surprisingly peaked at a 4 in the dry finish.  Light carbonation with a medium body.  Easy drinking, and not too bad.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: nice malty aroma - hazy brown/orange pour with medium fluffy light brown head - notes of carmel and citrus hops but a bit too bitter for the style, this doesnt necessarily mean that it is bad as it is overall a pretty good beer

Draft at Stanton Public. Poured a clear medium orange color with an off white head. Smelled of light grass and caramel. Light to medium bodied with grass, toffee, caramel, and steeping barley flavors. Decent.
On tap at Zeitgeist, San Francisco, 27th March 09, with Phyllis. Clear mid amber. Lightly hopped ESB taste. Moderately full palate. Decent but not really impressive.
tap. Pours with a brown color. fairly mellow in flavor as well as aroma. Some caramel notes and a bit of fairly light hops, easy drinking session beer.

On tap at McGilvras. Pretty standard ESB - like a barley wine without the bite (or the flavor, for that matter). Crisp and clean, with citrus hops balancing caramel malts, which dominate the brew. Not at all bad.

Poured from the 22 oz bottle a rich amber with an off-white head and good lacing. Good nose of caramel malts and floral and  citrus hops. Smooth clean mouthfeel. Flavor is lightly bitter and so is the finish.  A very easy to drink beer.
Very good. Not especially bitter as other esbs, but still delicious. Perfect as a drink after a stressful day at work.

I might be a huge beer geek, but I really kind of want this label as a tattoo. But anyways a very good bitter, one of my favorite. Pours a wonderful golden hue, very earthy hop profile. The hops are soft unlike an IPA, the result is bitter without that being THE taste. Malty throughout.
Bottle.  Pours nice tan amber with lingering head.  Mild aroma but has a nice balance of hops and sweetness (vanilla and mild caramel).  Smooth with clean finish.
Tap at Tangletown; not a complex bitterness, very relaxed; more malty then I expected and a bit flat. (#51)

22oz bottle from Liquid solutions.  Pours a medium murky brown with a 2 finger beige head.  Nose of toasted malts, and some herbal and citrus hops.  Flavor is very roasty with a good balance of bitter hops.

Dirty brown honey colored body.  Oxidized crystal malt nose with a surprisingly striking amount of sharp, pungent and stale noble-like hop scents.  I could not have guessed Cascade had any part to do with this beer, but Chinook for bittering makes complete sense, just have to adjust your taste around the unnecessary oxidized caramel character.  Bitter, pungent and messy.  I ended up pouring most of this out.
Bottle from Whole Foods Portland.  Very hoppy smell because this is basically a red.  And a fine one.  Bright appley malts balance very bright and green hops nicely.  Liked it a great deal!

20090130  Bomber from Spirits RB.  Dark copper colored with small, lingering beige head that laces.  Pine forest aromas, earthy with light notes of tobacco and those candied fruitcake fruits.  Medium-full and coating on the palate, yet with quenching, tempered bitterness.  Nice pine and resin notes, earthy malts, some tea hints, lingering bitterness.

Pours an amber color with a thin white head and minimal lacing... The aroma while pleasing is faint with notes of caramel and floral hops... Tastes is a bit creamy as it should be, with notes of floral hops and sweet malts, but not the traditional sweet malts i expect in an ESB... The finish is a bit on the thin side with a bit of a lingering metallic taste...

22 oz. bottle. Pours a deep caramel with a strong, pillowy head (looks like ice cream). Aroma is of vanilla, caramel, dust, and overpowering cascades. Taste is first bitter with a little sweetness, followed by a strong bitter finish. Needs a bit more complexity. Not nearly as good as others but not bad.

Pours a filtered amber color from the bomber with a full off-white head that leaves plenty of lacing.  Smells like a pale ale, but finishes like a bitter.  Tastes of orange rind, grapefruity hops, and pine sap.  A bit flat.
on draft at elysian, hoppy with only a slight bitter take to it. Typically watered down palate.

In the bomber bottle from Cousin Andrew. Dark orange amber with a medium to large off white head. Good grassy and floral hop aroma. Sweet fruity flavor that has a mild hop bitterness. Good, not great.
bottle, grapefruit orange cloudy pour, huge lasting latte head with lots of lacing, aroma of piney citrus and bread, malty flavor with sticky pine bitterness, finish is smooth fruit

tap @ brewery.  Nice golden pour with retention on glass.  Restrained malts and decent hops are well balanced but a little subdued.  Overall a nice brew with a clean finish after a toasty malty biscuity touch while allowing for a little hop wiggle-room.

Poured a nice coppery color with a slghtly off white head that had some retention.  Aroma had nice rich hop notes as well as earthy malt notes.  Flavor had a decent hop kick with some malts to balance it out. The malt notes were not the sweet kind.  The finish was nice and dry.

Big and full earthy scents with some citrus thrown in for good measure. Lightly flecked with something throughout the flavor, but whatever it is the sensation isn’t unpleasant. Well balanced and pretty solid overall.

22oz. Bottle:  Sweet aroma.  Smells of malts, citrus, grapefruit, hops, light butter, toasting, and some bread.  Poured amber in color with a small, creamy, rocky, off-white head that diminished but left a film that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Slightly sparkling.  Good to very good lacing.  Tiny particles throughout.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of malts, toasting, hops, pine, resin, tar, light citrus, and buttery yeast.  Medium body.  Thin body.  Average carbonation.  Malty, hoppy, finish.

Bottle. Pours orange amber with an off white head. The aroma is floral and earthy with some sweeter caramel notes. The flavor is a tad acidic, floral hoppy and just enough malt to balance. Pretty good.
I had this in bottle and on cask. The cak was really great. Very smooth and balanced. Malt sweetness and some bitterness. Some other flavors come through of hints of fruit and earth. Very good.

Thanks to Justin for sharing this bottle. Pours out a well carbonated moderate hue of amber with a moderate, rather nice tanish head. Aroma is sweet and malty, but well balanced with some grassy/slightly citrus hops. Taste is complex and well balanced sweet malts and some fruity notes blend with a nice hop profile, some grass and citrus, bitter finish. Usually not my style, but pretty well done.
Bomber.  Pours a mahogany brown body with an off white 1 finger head.  Sweet malty, brown sugar, light citrus hops.  Light chocolate flavor.  Light pine and moderate chocolate.  Good beer.

22 ounce bottle split in pint glass.  Reddish amber with lasting beige head and lace.  Hoppy fresh toasted brown sugar aroma.  Mild brown sugar and fruit with nice hoppy bitterness.  Medium body and medium carbo.  Excellent soft mouthfeel.  Nice and fresh because Elysian just came to NY.  Excellent.

Cask @ Blind Tiger. Pours cloudy orange-amber, with a big-bubbled, sticky off-white head. Nose is full of sweet citrus, with just a bit of resiny pine underneath. Taste is a hop blast from top to bottom - sweet malt up front sits underneath a slightly prickly hop bitterness that hints of citrus, with the resiny pine coming up big towards the finish. Finish prickly pine, bitter, dry and lingering, with hints of biscuit and citrus as well. Mouthfeel is smooth, creamy and full, with the barest hint of prickly carbonation underneath. Really a nice experience on cask.

Draft. Amber beer with an off-white head. Malty aroma with some floral notes. malt, light caramel flavor with more floral/grassy hops. Medium body. Easy drinking. Malt, floral tones, and light fruit linger.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2009 Rerate; previous rating was 3.8.  It wasnt as good for me this time, thinking it was about a 3.3/4 overall.  I still thought it was solid for the style, just not quite great.

On tap at OBriens.  Poured a dark caramel orange, with a smallish whie head.  Aroma of toffee, caramel, grass, fruit and citrus.  Flavor was well hopped for the style, almost as much as an IPA.  Nice balanced flavor with caramel and then grassy and fruity.  Just solid, clean flavors; really good for the style.

Murky deep orange hue, small off-white head, moderate lacing. Nose is clean crisp malts, light fruit sweetness, pine hops, spices, overall quite subtle. Taste is grainy biscuit malts and grassy/earthy hops, caramel, light fruits, finish is very dry. Palate is medium-full, creamy texture, and prickly carbonation. Overall a nice and balanced ESB with a straight-forward profile of bitter and dry hops and complementary malts, easy drinking.

Bottle, thanks to WeeHeavySD for sharing. Pours a clear amber-red with a thick, foamy, off-white head. Aroma of spices, malt, citrus, pine hops, and herbs. Taste is spicy and clean, of malt, herbs, and pine hops. Lingering sharp spiciness. Tasty.

bomber from bottleworks in seattle.  deep copper pour with a thick off-white head.  tea, malt, biscuits and a bit of funk in the aroma.  follows form except for the funk -- with caramel sweetness and bready malts.  well balanced.  bitterness comes through late.  pretty good.  K-8

Draft at Pacific Standard in Brooklyn.  Clear copper pour with small, soft off-white yellowish head.  A better-than-average ESB, with nice malt to back up the strong and tasty bitter northwest hops.  Biscuity on the mid palate and crisply bitter at the end.  Nice.

Bottle with a new style label. Clear copper with a fleeting tan  head. Mild aroma is earthy malts and toffee. Medium body. Strong flavors are sweet caramel malts with a nice spicy hop bitterness to balance things. Another throwback to early PacNW micros.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Poured slightly hazy rust color, a bit of tan head and good lacing. Aroma is very mild, some earthy sweetness. Nice medium bodied smooth mouthfeel. Taste is mostly grass and caramel, a bit of roasty-ness. Lingering bitter finish.

Bomber poured a clear reddish amber with a small lingering ring of amber foam. Aromas of earthiness, toffee, burnt carmel and light pine. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a slightly dry finish. Flavors of carmel, earthiness, light toffee and hints of fruittiness and pine with a smooth dry moderatly bitter finish.
Draft. nice chocolatish aroma I thought to make nice sessionable ESB. I likey.
bottle gift from Mark. Opened it after a rough night of work. poured a copper color with malty aroma, not too much hops on the nose. Smooth hop taste though, with a medium body. An easy drinking ESB.
on tap @ Blind Tiger. Copper colored pour. Aromas of malts & PNW hops. Taste has a nice hop presence to go along with malt dominance. Very good ESB

Bomber I bought in January.  Pours copper with a tan head.  Nose is very nice, very sweet, and malty.  Taste is very nicely malty with a hopped backbone.  Usually I find this style boring but this is certainly tasty.

Pours a medium brown color, with a moderate, foamy lace - very bready aroma, with earthy hops underneath, and a bit of mineral character - nicely bittered and herbal up front, followed by some bread/toast and buttery flavor - gets a little caramel sweetness after that, but not enough to steal the show from the bitterness - hops come in for a second wave near the finish, adding a spicy/peppery kick - a bit hoppier than your traditional ESB, but it is American, after all.
Cask conditioned.  Light brown pour with fluffy head and decent lace. Hoppy aroma.  Malts and hops (piney) pretty well balanced

Pours dark amber with a modest head. Good amount of lacing. Dark hoppy aroma. Big bitter hop flavors with a forward malt flavor to match. Well almost. Quality ESB with enough hops for most ESB drinkers.

22oz bottle. Bitter hop aroma. Dark amber in color with a thick off white head. Good balance of bitter hops and malt. Most of the flavor is defined by the hops with are abundant. You can definitely taste the Columbus hops. A different ESB, but good.
Pours copper amber color with foamy offwhite head.  Watery caramel malt.  Slight piney hop.  Nothing special.

Tap at Blind Tiger. Aroma primarily citrus and floral hops, seems more like a light IPA than an ESB. Also got some styrofoam, but it wasn’t really enough to put a damper on the experiene. The flavor brings out more of the toasted malt typical of ESB’s, with the hops acting as bittering supporters. It actually had a casky mouthfeel to me...don’t know what that was all about. Pretty good, nothing mindblowing.

On tap at Blind Tiger.  Pours a clear brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt.  Flavor of sweet malt, slightly hoppy (citrus, pine), although the beer is dominated by the malt flavors.  Some butteriness and burnt toast emerges in the finish.  Nice and refreshing.

Draught @ Elysian Field. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Malty hoppy pine needles aroma with hints of caramel. Sweet malty and fruity caramel flavor with piny hoppy hints. Sweetish malty caramel finish with nice hoppy finish.

Draught at Bar Great Harry.  Deep copper color poured with a small frothy off-white head, leaving squiggles of lacing.  Aromas of toffee, tea, citrus and earthy hops.  Rich and surprisingly complex flavor of caramel/tofee malts with a nice spicy bite to it.  Almost like a spiced peach or dried apricot fruitiness throughout, with citrus, earthy and piney hops on the finish.  Not sure if this is quite your British great uncle’s ESB,  but damn if it’s not a tasty little ale.
Wonderful, medium-bodied ESB with caramel malts and a smooth, creamy, honeyed floral character.  Excellent American spin on an ESB.

Maybe I was really thirsty for beer today but this one really hit the spot after doing some yard work.  Pours  light amber without a sustainable head.  Aroma is good ol west coast hops.  Flavor is the same, but not overdone and more refreshing.  I cant believe I lived in the Seattle area for 6 years and never got around to trying this beer.

Dark amber.  Nose not to type ... with strong notes of PNW hops no one at Fullers would recognize this as an ESB.  Taste is more dry, less malty, with far more PNW American hops than one would expect from an ESB.
At Humpys in Anchorage. Old world style. Pretty good. Weak head. Like an old world bitter. A bit watery, but expected from the style. Ive had better American ESBs, notably Alaska ESB.

Sample at the Pike Street location. Pours a clear dark copper color with a compact and creamy off-white head that lasts awhile. Patches of lacing. Hops boquet in the nose, with a hint of line. Medium, smooth body with flavors of hops and malt with a piney undertone. The finish is hoppy and malty with a lingering pine and citrus aftertaste. Hoppier than a lot of ESBs, and pretty enjoyable overall.

This brews really subtle flavors are what make it great.  Bottle... Poured ruby with some orange and thin white head.  Aroma, has chocolate-malt and sweet yeast and grains.  Very smooth and easy feeling in the mouth and the malt flavors hit up front while hops began to take over giving it some depth towards the finish.  Either Im starting to enjoy ESBs more, or Im having a string of some pretty good ones, but this one hits the button for me.
Bottle, sample courtesy of walleye. Clear copper, no head, oily. Faint bitterness up front, w/o much else. Flavor much the same, light bitterness, w/o  any malt backbone.

clear amber pour,with thin creamy white head.this is one of the most balanced,and drinkable beers out there.the one question i have is,why arent  bitters more popular.there malty,there hoppy, good middle ground for everyone

[1108-20080217] Tap @ Elysian Fields (Seattle, WA). Mild malt grains aroma. Clear, brown amber body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head and a thick lace coating. Same grainy rye and crusty bread yeast continues in flavour with a long finish. Medium-full body is a little boozy. Interesting.

On tap, was just what I was looking for.  Pretty mild in most areas, though it has a great light body and full head.  The flavor showcases bitter hops without being too bitter.   Not my favorite style, but definitely would order again.

One of my favorites out of the sampler at the Elysian brewpub. An example of moderation, not too harsh, not too mellow; not too fizzy, not too carbonated, etc. Left me wishing I had ordered a full glass.
Bronze with big head that laces like a like your white-washing the glass. Strict quick hop hit with a good balance at the end. Nice ESB.
Pours brown, slight white head. Nice aroma, decent body, all around a solid ESB, but nothing special
22oz bottle...deep copper color with small white head.  up front is hops and citrus.  the finish is mellow and slightly sweet which evens out the hops

Draft pint at Humpys.  Rusty red, the color borders on bronze.  The head is quite gluey, leaving a curtain-like wall down the glass.  This comes across very tea-like overall -- leafy and bitter.  If it were hot, you might convince me this was Earl Grey.  (#3298, 1/19/2008)

From a 22oz. purchased at New Seasons Seven Corners location in Portland, Oregon--Poured a rich amber-copper with a medium but healthy white head, leaving thick tall lacing.  Bold caramel sweet, sticky hop/malt esters.  Quite easy drinking and enjoyable.  I could drink this beer everyday without a problem.  Great hop profile and subtle finish.  A wise choice no doubt!

Sampled during Cheesehead YeHA in Brookfield, Wisconsin and shared by MIBRomeo. Pours a clear amber brew with a fast dissolving off-white head with good lacing and a thin white ring. Aroma of light caramel malt, a touch of iced tea, and some piney hops. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonated with flavors of multi-grained caramel malt, some citrus and piney character with some earthy herbs. Finish is slightly bitter with a light iced tea aftertaste and a lingering mild bitterness.

light caramel color, tall foamy white head w/ nice lace.  Caramely aroma w/ light alcohols and some sweet grains.  Nice palate well coated.  Nice lightly bitter piney resinous taste a bit of caramel, easy to drin.  a nice little esb.

Hazy copper colored pour with minimal head but with nice lacing from a colorfully labeled 1.6 pint bottle. This premium ESB starts strong with its pedigreed bittering hops but the balance returns toward the finish and the drinker is happy.
bottle. Citric hop nose. Murky orange brown. Roasted cookie malt base, fruit, light brown sugar mellow citric and tropical hops. Chewy body. Sparkly.
a dark coppery colour with a light white head. a nice easy bitterness but not an extra bitter. enjoyable overall

bottle from kenb...pours on the brown side of copper with a fluffy off white head. aroma is of sweet malts, orange, earth (like the dirt on carrots) and pine hops. the flavor is everything in the aroma but with a strange bitter rubber flavor (kinda like chewing on an eraser) that hangs around the spicy herbal finish.( im not sure if the off rubber flavor is just me or its intentional)floral and pine hops linger in the aftertaste. medium bodied with a bunch of carbonation. needs a rerate

Bottle. Orange/red beverage with a sunburst pure pleasure to look at. Aroma of melon-first fruitiness, balanced by wood/cardboard and hops. Balanced bitterness dominates the palate, with a nice gritty palate and some fruitiness coming through towards the middle. A very-well-made ESB.
Bottle. Dark orange pour with an off-white head. Aroma of bright earthy hops and caramel malt. Flavors of caramel and earthy hops. Medium body, bittersweet/a bit watery with a bitter finish.

Bomber from Liquid Solutions. 3" of ale and 5" of head! Aroma of floral hop. Reddish tinged amber color with a truly humongous off-white head. Medium bodied with vigorous carbonation. The flavor is floral hop backed by caramel. Theres nut and citrus and pine, but its best to see it as floral. Swonderful. The finish is nicely balanced with malt and hop. Seems a bit thinner at the end, but its still incredibly tasty. The English could learn from this.

Bottle from Larry Pitonka/5000. Pour was deep orangey amber in color, very generous whitish colored head, great lacing and retention for the style. The aroma was is full malty caramel with some citrus and piney hops. The flavor was full caramel, a touch of nutty toffee, but lots of piney hops, citrus notes, and faint spicey aspects. Full and creamy body, well carbonated. Thanks, Andre!

Pours a orange-amber with an immortal head - the darn thing just never dies! Beautiful thick head & lacing. Aroma of sudsy hops. Tastes marvellous - great malt backbone and excellent hopping, albeit Pacific Northwest hops for a style of British origin. Normally that would throw me off, but the maltiness is very reassuring. Creamy body, moderate carb. This tastes just shy of an American IPA but with enough malt to satisfy any fan of the style. Nicely done!
1.6 pint bottle.  Nice Copper color and a fine head.  Good malt flavor and the chinook and Cascade are really pronounced.  Although I do not taste the Colombus.

Pours a dark copper with a medium white head.
Aroma is toasty caramel maltiness with an orange  and pine hop. 
Decent body, nice bitterness though something lacking to make it an exceptional bitter.

10/20 On draught at the Capitol Hill brewery.  Aroma is cascade and citrus hops with a rather low malt note.  Appearance is clear gold with a medium white head.  Flavor is balanced but too PNW hoppy for style, not too bitter or English enough.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a medium carb texture.  This is not a bad beer and is easy drinking for style; its just too hop-heavy and americanized.

Bomber from jake65 - thanks, Jake!  Big, fat malty aroma, sticky caramel with funky hops that arent afraid to get down and dirty!  Faint pine.  Deep amber pour with a soapy, creeping beige head.  Taste is lightly bitter but smacks of hops, especially the finishs and aftertaste.  Bready caramel, thick malt with a deft touch of water-sucking resin.  Medium body and quaffable.  Pretty excellent for style (Ami ESB), but somethings off here; not metallic, but not  especially warm and inviting - the hops are a little too raw.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 old rating:
6/4/7/3/15 - 3.5

pours a clear dark copper with a small light beige head, and good lacing.

smell is of toffee, roasted nuts, a touch of citrus, malt, and some grapefruit hops.

taste is creamy, caramel, roasted nuts, malt, a touch of citrus, hops in the back, and a touch of pine, end is a little dry and a little bitter.
On tap at Elysian Brewing Seattle, pours out a amber topped with a off white cream head. Nice malt along with a touch of wood on this one. A little hop bitterness makes this a very tasty ESB.

A great ESB with more hops than typical.  Good color, warm aroma, and well-balanced between the carmel malts and bitterness.  Had this one at the brewery on Capital Hill - not sure if the bottled version would fair as well.

Copper color. Good lasting head. Easy drinker especially with the 5.9%. Wish more bombers were this strength. Not to sweet and not to much of a hoppy finish. I could drink this regularily if it were available here.

Bottle courtesy of SS: Poured a deep copper color ale with large fluffy head with average retention. Aroma of NW bitter hops is dominating with some nice caramel. Taste is probably bitterer then the style would suggest but who cares. Caramel malt is present and provides a nice balance. Good carbonation with a full body.

On tap at Capital Hill Brewery.
Great amber color.  Aroma is of malt and hops.  I was surprised how hoppy this was.  The malt is maybe not enough for me, but still it is a good beer.

Nice copper color, with an off white and fluffy head. Nice a slightly astringent hop notes. Goood medium malts, with a touch of carmel, and nice hops, slighty bitter hop notes. Mostly grapefruit, not bad at all.

amber, thin off white head, slightly sweet malt aroma with a touch of floral hops, soft bitter flavor with a low bitter finish
